body.p: Two methods, A and B, are available for teaching a certain industrial skill. There is an 80% chance of successfully learning the skill if method A is used, and a 95% chance of success if method B is used. However, method B is substantially more expensive and is therefore used only 25% of the time (method A is used the other 75% of the time). The following notations are suggested:

ul.li: L—the skill was L earned successfully

body.p: Which of the following is the correct representation of the information that is provided to us?

response.feedback: Correct. There is an 80% chance of learning the skill if method A is used → P(L|A) = 0.80. There is a 95% chance of learning the skill if method B is used → P(L|B) = 0.95. Method B is used 25% of the time → P(B) = 0.25 → P(not B) = P(A) = 0.75.

Incorrect. Recall that if method A is used, then there is an 80% chance of successfully learning the skill and if method B is used, then there is a 95% probability of learning the skill. In other words, given that you have used method A or B, you will learn the skill with probability 80% or 95%, respectively.

Incorrect. P(A and L) represents the probability that a randomly chosen person has both learned the skill and used method A. P(B and L) represents the probability that a randomly chosen person has both learned the skill and used method B. Recall that given method A is used, the probability of successfully learning the skill is 80%. Also, given that method B is used, the probability of successfully learning the skill is 95%.

Incorrect. P(A | L) represents the probability that a randomly chosen person that learned the skill successfully has learned the skill using method A. Similarly, P(B | L) represents the probability that a randomly chosen person that learned the skill successfully has learned the skill using method B.Recall that method A is used 75% of the time because it costs less than using method B, which is used 25% of the time.

Incorrect. P(A and L) represents the probability that a randomly chosen person has both learned the skill and used method A. P(B and L) represents the probability that a randomly chosen person has both learned the skill and used method B. Recall that methods A and B are used 75% and 25% of the time, respectively.

body.p: Two methods, A and B, are available for teaching a certain industrial skill. There is an 80% chance of successfully learning the skill if method A is used, and a 95% chance of success if method B is used. However, method B is substantially more expensive and is therefore used only 25% of the time (method A is used the other 75% of the time). The following notations are suggested:
Which of the following is the correct probability tree for this problem?

response.feedback: Incorrect. In this case, the events occur in stages: first you must choose which method to use, second you must see whether the person successfully learns the skill or not. This ordering should be exemplified in the probability tree by putting the first stage before the second.

Incorrect. Remember that probability trees must have the following property: the sum of the probabilities of each branch coming from a common point must be 1. This means that if you have two branches coming out of a single point, the probability of branch 1 plus the probability of branch 2 must be 1.
Correct. The first stage is choosing the method, A or B with P(A) = 0.75 and P(B) = 0.25. The second stage is either learning or not learning the skill. with P(L | A) = 0.80) and P(L | B) = 0.95.

Incorrect. Because the first stage of the tree starts with A on the top branch and B on the bottom branch, the second set of branches in the tree must be have conditional probabilities (from top to bottom) of: P(L | A), P(not L | A), P (L | B), and P (not L | B). It appears you switched the conditional probability values for A and B.

There is an 80% chance of successfully learning the skill if method A is used, and a 95% chance of success if method B is used. However, method B is substantially more expensive and is therefore used only 25% of the time (method A is used the other 75% of the time). The following notations are suggested:
What is the probability that a randomly chosen worker will learn the skill successfully?

response.feedback: Incorrect. It seems that you have calculated P(A and L). However, P(L) = P(A and L) + P (not A and L) = P(A and L) + P(B and L). Recall that you have four pieces of information: P(A) = 0.75, P(B) = 0.25, P (L | A) = 0.80, P(L | B) = 0.95. Using these, you can apply the Law of Total Probability to find P (L).

Connect. We need to find P(L). Using the tree, we need to identify the “paths” in the tree to ‘L’, multiply the probabilities along each of those paths, and then add the resulting probabilities. In this case P(L) = 0.75 * 0.80 + 0.25 * 0.95 = 0.60 + 0.2375 = 0.8375.
